misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Loop-control confusion (believing the loop variable will ‘take care of itself’/update correctly)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the inner loop will automatically count `j` from 1 up to `i` and stop, even if they increment `i` inside the inner loop header.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, the third part of a `for` loop header is executed exactly as written after each iteration of that loop. Writing `i++` in the inner loop means the *outer* loop counter is advanced during the inner loop’s execution, while `j` never changes. This breaks the intended nested-loop model (outer loop controls rows, inner loop controls columns).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Non-terminating loop and/or incorrect output (prints `*` indefinitely because `j` stays 1 and `i` keeps increasing, so `j <= i` remains true).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Statement grouping misconception (thinking formatting/indentation defines what repeats)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the code after the inner loop will execute once per row and that the inner loop will only include the `System.out.print("*")`, based on how they visually structured it on one line.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java uses braces `{}` (or a single following statement) to determine what belongs to a loop—not indentation or “how it looks” on the page. Here, because the inner loop has no braces, only `System.out.print("*")` is in the inner loop; `System.out.println();` is outside it. This part is actually correct for the desired pattern, but combined with the wrong increment (`i++` instead of `j++`), the student’s mental model of the nested structure likely doesn’t match what the compiler executes.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Contributes to misunderstanding of what repeats; in this specific program the bigger symptom is still the infinite/incorrect inner loop behavior.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that incrementing the inner loop counter (i++) will somehow advance through iterations correctly, possibly thinking that the same variable increment operation works identically regardless of context or that the increment happens automatically.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has written `j<=i;i++` in the inner for loop, incrementing `i` instead of `j`. This creates an infinite loop because `j` never increments, so `j` will always be 1 and always be <= i. The outer loop variable `i` gets incremented by the inner loop, skipping values and causing unpredictable behavior. The student likely confused which variable should be incremented or didn't carefully track which loop each part of the for statement belongs to.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The program will either hang/freeze (infinite loop on the first iteration) or produce incorrect output because the inner loop counter never advances, and the outer loop variable is being modified unexpectedly by the inner loop.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that 'i' is the universal counter for the program's progress and that incrementing it in the inner loop's header will correctly drive the triangle's construction.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's nested for-loops, each loop must independently manage its own control variable. The student fails to understand that the inner loop's guard (j <= i) relies on the inner variable (j) reaching a limit; by incrementing 'i' instead of 'j', the inner loop's condition will always remain true, resulting in an infinite loop.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Loop Counter Autopilot (confusing which variable a loop updates)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes the inner loop will automatically advance its own counter (j) even if they increment a different variable, so writing `i++` inside the inner loop will still behave like “move to the next column”.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, loop control variables do not update “by loop level” automatically—only the exact variable named in the update clause changes. Here, the inner loop updates `i` instead of `j`, so `j` stays 1 forever. Because the condition is `j <= i` and `i` keeps increasing, the inner loop never terminates (effectively an infinite loop printing `*`). The outer loop’s `i` is also being modified unexpectedly inside the inner loop, breaking the intended row/column separation in a nested-loop pattern.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime non-termination / infinite output (prints `*` forever until manually stopped).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that as long as there is an increment statement in the for loop, the loop will properly iterate the correct number of times. They may not fully understand that the variable being incremented must match the variable being tested in the loop condition.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, the for loop syntax is for(init; condition; increment). The increment statement must modify the variable tested in the condition to properly control loop termination. Here, j is tested but i is incremented, creating an infinite loop where j never changes. The student's mental model appears to treat the increment as a generic 'driver' rather than understanding it must specifically advance the loop counter being evaluated.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Infinite loop - the program will print asterisks forever because j is never incremented, so the condition j<=i never becomes false

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that incrementing the outer loop's control variable (i) inside the header of the inner loop is the correct way to progress the program or that the specific variable being incremented in the for-loop update clause does not strictly need to match the variable being tested in the condition.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's execution model, a nested for-loop requires its own independent control variable to reach a termination state. By incrementing the outer variable 'i' instead of 'j', the condition 'j <= i' will always evaluate to true (as i increases while j remains constant), creating an infinite loop and simultaneously corrupting the iteration logic of the outer loop.
